We're ok, really. The good people of America funneled almost $85B over two years into Louisiana to help us get it back together and as far as I can tell most of that money was well spent.

The tricky part was deciding which parts of the state go on the back of the new floodwall system, and who gets to live on the exposed side.

Wouldn't have wanted to make THAT decision.

But we are grateful here for the generosity of AMericans of all stripes, inside government and outside.

WR29

I did get a lot of that type of feedback too, but I understand that there is simply no way to appreciate the devastation of a Katrina without living through it. I didn't think worse of my northern brethren during that time.

Now I suspect there will be no more insensitive responses from those in the northeast since they have had a taste of what it's like to be truly not in control of anything.

Nature wins. Gave over.....Terrifying.

WR29

Sorry to say, but typically in these situations the power will stay out for an extended period of time, sometimes weeks. There simply aren't enough lineman and equipment in the world to repair the amount of damage done by even the smallest hurricane.

At least it's not August in south Louisiana, where without electricty you have older folks dropping dead right and left from heat exhaustion and dehydration. If the weather can stay above 50 or so they should be fine. It's often more dangerous to move around than just to stay put.

I was disturbed on the news to see so many folks who refused evacuation orders. Down here our emergency folks have learned, and they no longer will put their own lives on the line for the folks who simply are too hard-headed to leave.

I can't really blame them there.

As far as the storm and its intensity goes, it was wicked big even by hurricane standards, very late in the year as well, but the damage is exacerbated over earlier storms because the population is so much bigger and so many folks like to live on the water nowadays. That makes them awfully vulnerable to even the smallest tidal surges.

WR29

During Katrina, we got aid from France faster than we did from FEMA. I kid you not, actual cash donations and French citizens with the Red Cross.

It was quite amazing.

Unregulated prices and secure property rights, in an emergency situation, are invitations to pricing for maximum return rather than distribution for maximum utility (otherwise known as price gouging). Rich hoarders who want extra just to be safe will outbid desperate ordinary citizens who may be in a life or death situation.

Disasters can be opportunities to make a lot of money if laws and regulations allow it. I dont think they should. The government should promote free enterprise but not scams. Of course, from a certain point of view there are no scams, only losers who made mistakes they did not have to make.
Sure.  Damage is done in NJ and coastal areas.  But the whining from the city-bound NYers re slow subways and internet is real and completely out of touch.
I agree with you Lynne.

Most of the people in the dark in lower manhattan are not rich yuppies - they already fled while the rest of us mon-car owners are stranded.  No services, no ice, no groceries.  romney's "relief" trucks ain't reaching us!

For those who complain that New Yorkers (sic) are whining about slow subways and closed wine shops, I advise them to turn on the news. Your vitriol - and downright glee - makes no sense as it is, but have you seen what has transpired in EIGHT states? This is not yuppie griping; Many people have lost everything, and some have lost their lives. Not to mention, we did prepare, and everyone in leadership, regardless of politics, did an outstanding job. Is the body count not high enough for you to display basic human decency and quit point-scoring? It's disgusting.

It gives a strange perspective that the early estimates for damage from this storm, which was huge, are less than estimates for crop loss from the bad weather this summer.  Perhaps, if the numbers hold up, we've already seen worse this year.  Let us hope the pace of disaster relents for us.
God save the all people with their family.

In an event as huge as this storm, people in the direct path will never be able to plan enough. Stock up on food, charge your cellphone, get more batteries and candles... You can do everything recommended and still be the police officer who shepherded people to safety then drowned in his own basement, or the young woman who went out to take a photo and was killed by a snapped electrical line. Please. Let us take some time to get over this.

to CMS -Tennessee:

Actually I was responding to two replies that presumed incorrectly that I would be under water too.

My primary point is to ask people to see further ahead and plan appropriately.

Unfortunately, private industry has a bad reputation too! Take the health insurance industry--rife with greed and power as they ration out care to accommodate their shareholder's needs for profits.

Or, how about the military industrial complex--whoa, that industry is filled to the brim with n'er do wells.

What we need are real representatives in Congress--men and women beholden to the voter, and not in the pockets of private industry. We have the best Congress money can buy--the end of democracy.

Here's an example of "government efficiency"--Medicare. Medicare's overhead is 2%. Private insurance companies' overhead? Now limited by law to 20% (thanks to Al Franken.) It was formerly about 25%. And what is job 1 for private insurance companies? Making sure that it's customers lack coverage for health problems. What is Medicare's job 1? Providing health insurance.

How about hospitals? When most hospitals were owned by cities and municipalities, do you think there was a problem with doctors running up hospital bills by doing work on patients that wasn't necessary? Now they have a profit motive. Then they were on salary. No wonder health costs have risen so quickly in the US, but not in Canada or Europe.

There are many examples of the inefficiency of private industry due to conflicts of interest and greed. Some industries are better run by (well regulated) private business. Many are not.

The typical straw man argument.

Your "This is just one small example of government efficiency" equates to one big example of ignorance.

The Netherlands is never a good comparison given that they've never actually been hit  by a hurricane.

@Kailliland
The arctic storms that strike the Netherlands every winter have similar causes and wind velocities.

This is maybe a half-baked idea: Would it make sense to build flood barriers across the Narrows and the southern end of the Arthur Kill, sort of like (but larger) than the Netherlands' Delta Works and the Thames Barrier in England? The latter and some of the former are still navigable to shipping, as these proposed barriers would have to be. I can see two problems: One, the cost (ca. $10 billion)? Two, even if the barriers stopped a storm surge from the open ocean, would there still be enough water behind the barriers (city-side of the barriers) that a storm surge would cause massive flooding from this water alone?
PS to flood barrier comment: There would also have to be a barrier at Throgs Neck.

Underground lines create two new problems that are every bit as daunting as overhead lines being blown down by storms and trees:

1. TRANSFORMERS when put underground have to be sealed in such a way as to prevent water from standing in the boxes. And if that water happens to be sea water, protecting them is almost impossible.
2. FAULTS are almost impossible to find, and when found huge sections of the line must be dug up and replaced and great expense, time and inconvenience.

IN addition, many urban areas ALREADY have underground services, but in a saltwater storm surge, it really just makes things worse.

After katrina, the city's natural gas pipeline infrastructure (that went to the homes in the city for a variety of things like cooking, hot water, and heating) sprung leaks because of the overpressure of 10 feet of muddy, nasty water overhead. The system literally have to be blown out, foot by foot, and took two solid years to get back in service.

We are rapidly moving to the tipping point of Global Warming. These weather patterns are becoming the norm, and it's only going to get worse. The only thing that will allow us to stop the momentum and have any hope of repairing even some of the damage is if we KEEP THE FOSSIL FUELS IN THE GROUND. ALL OF THEM.

The odds of that happening, of course, are pretty much nil. By the time things get so bad that people demand change it will be far too late.

Ultimately, the real problem with a storm like Sandy is simply this: We ain't seen nothing yet.

The money paid into the Social Security system has been replaced with a promise - from politicians.

I've been reading Arthur Schlesinger Jr's The Age of Jackson, and what's been going on lately was happening back in the early-mid 19th century.  A wealthy economic aristocracy felt it was smarter and better than the 99% of underlings, and thought it should be running the country.  Hamilton said it outright.  Later the conservatives learned the art of deception, put up a democratic facade but worked for the interests of the plutocrats.  Sound familiar? Another book I find relevant to our trying times: Professor Brands' Traitor to his Class on FDR, who gave us Social Security.  SS has a 1% administrative overhead and is good for the next quarter of a century.  With minor adjustments, for the next 75 years (See Dean Baker at Center for Economic Policy and Research).  The wealthy considered FDR a traitor because he used government to help the average citizen, not just the rich.  As far as being an "entitlement,"  ordinary folks pay into it for decades.  It's not a charity.  A real charity was bailing out the big banks with no strings attached.  The financiers want the government to protect them but not regulate them.  Again, according to Dean Baker (Ph.D. in economics, not a corporate prostitute).
